Generation II.Gold: The shell on its back is just skin that has cooled and hardened. It breaks easily with a slight touch.
Generation II.Silver: Its brittle shell occasionally spouts intense flames that circulate throughout its body.
Generation II.Crystal: Its body is as hot as lava and is always billowing. Flames will occasionally burst from its shell.
Generation II.Stadium 2: The shell on its back is just skin that has cooled and hardened. It breaks easily with a slight touch. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) Its brittle shell occasionally spouts intense flames that circulate throughout its body. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: Magcargo 's shell is actually its skin that hardened as a result of cooling. Its shell is very brittle and fragile - just touching it causes it to crumble apart. This Pok é mon returns to its original size by dipping itself in magma.
Generation III.Sapphire: Magcargo 's body temperature is approximately 18,000 degrees F . Water is vaporized on contact. If this Pok é mon is caught in the rain, the raindrops instantly turn into steam, cloaking the area in a thick fog.
Generation III.Emerald: The shell on its back is made of hardened magma. Tens of thousands of years spent living in volcanic craters have turned Magcargo 's bodies into magma.

Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: Its body temperature is roughly 18,000 degrees Fahrenheit . Flames burst from gaps in its shell made of hardened magma.

Generation IX.Scarlet: This Pokémon lives near the craters of volcanoes. It stores fire energy in its shell of cooled and hardened magma.
Generation IX.Violet: According to folklore, a sudden increase in the wild Magcargo population heralds a volcanic eruption.
